I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The provision of technical assistance (TA) to AccessBank Tajikistan (ABTJ) supports an 
anticipated  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  investment  in  Tajikistan’s  finance  sector. 
Supporting private sector development and facilitating access to finance is one of the three 
development  goals  to  be  achieved  by  ADB’s  country  partnership  strategy  2010–2014  for 
Tajikistan. The TA would constitute ADB’s first nonsovereign investment in the country. On 21–
27 November 2013, ADB fielded a mission to Tajikistan and agreed with ABTJ, the targeted 
investee,  and  its  shareholders  on  the  design,  impact,  outcome,  outputs,  implementation 
arrangements, cost, financing arrangements, and terms of reference of the TA. The design and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1  
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  During 2007–2011, Tajikistan made substantial progress in per capita income growth of 
nearly 17% per annum; however, it remains one of the poorest countries in Central Asia with a 
per capita income of only $962 in the first quarter of 2013. Poverty remains widespread with a 
headcount ratio of 46.7% (2009). In rural areas, where more than 70% of the 8.0 million Tajiks 
live, poverty exceeds 50%.  
 
3.   In 2011, trade and services, the most important economic sectors, contributed about  
60% to value addition; agriculture and industry (including manufacturing) remain significant, 
each contributing 20%. The services sector has been the most dynamic with a compounded 
annual growth rate of 14.4% (2007–2011), outpacing agriculture (6.3%) and industry (1.7%) 
during the same period. The lower growth of agricultural value added points to the country’s low 
productivity  and  less  favorable  income  growth  for  the  rural  population.  Tajikistan  draws 
substantial  benefits  from  cross-border  remittances  of  1.5  million  workers  in  the  Russian 
Federation. Remittance volumes have more than doubled since 2007 to $3.6 billion in 2012, 
equivalent to 47% of gross domestic product. The financial crisis of 2008–2009 weakened the 
Tajik economy until its recovery began in 2011. 
 
4.  The  private  sector  has  important  potential  to  contribute  to  income  generation  and 
employment.  However,  a  survey  of  entrepreneurs  in  Tajikistan,  conducted  by  the  World 
Economic Forum, rates access to finance, taxation, and corruption as the most challenging 
factors  impeding  business  growth.2 Micro,  small,  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (MSMEs) 
account for 33% of total employment; half is in agriculture. Microfinance institutions (MFIs) and 
donors via banks are the main providers of finance for microenterprises, smallholder farmers, 
and agricultural businesses.  
 
5.  Tajikistan’s finance sector has been exposed to banking crises in the post-Soviet period, 
which have weakened public confidence. Limited central bank independence from government 
has undermined financial intermediation progress, which is essential for economic growth. The 
ratio of bank assets to gross domestic product indicates low financial depth at only 27.6% 
(2011), far below other transition economies. In Tajikistan, only about 16% of households have 
access  to  formal  financial  services.  In  the  absence  of  competition,  intermediation  spreads 
between lending and deposit rates were as a high as 18% in 2010. Similar to other transition 
economies, deposit mobilization by the Tajikistan financial system is weak and highly dollarized 
as indicated by a high loan-to-deposit ratio of 127% (first quarter 2013); about 70% of deposits 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 24 December 2013. 
2  World Economic Forum. 2012. Global Competitiveness Report 2012-2013. Geneva.

2 
and 62% of loans are in hard currencies. This implies a high foreign exchange-induced credit 
risk for borrowers of financial institutions. 
 
6.  The finance sector includes 16 commercial banks, one nonbank, and 127 MFIs. With 
only  301  branches,  the  sector’s  reach  is  weak.  The  absence  of  skilled  bankers  and  the 
presence  of  a  culture  based  on  family  loyalty  rather  corporate  work  ethics  is  a  serious 
bottleneck that constrains the industry. Many of the banks do not have an MSME customer 
orientation, and most of the MFIs do not appear to have the strength, investors, and know-how 
to grow into sustainable businesses. Individuals who exercise strong control over their business 
dominate many of the smaller MFIs.  
 
7.  Although  MFIs  have  made  considerable  efforts  to  serve  poor  households  and 
businesses in  Tajikistan  and  have  contributed to  considerable  growth  of  microfinance,  the 
overall significance of their reach is still limited. MFI growth has been facilitated mainly by donor 
funding,  which  is  expected  to  continue  for  some  time  in  the  absence  of  strong  deposit 
mobilization.  Only  three  member  banks  and  15  MFIs  registered  with  the  Association  of 
Microfinance Organizations of Tajikistan (AMFOT) had more than 1,000 borrowing clients as of 
March 2013. The finance sector had $1,400 million equivalent of outstanding loans (first quarter 
2013); of these banks had 81.3% and AMFOT member MFIs 18.7%.  
 
8.  Demand for micro and small business loans in urban and rural areas is growing, partly 
buoyed by the substantial flow of remittances from out-of-country workers, which stimulates 
private demand. However, local commercial banks remain weak, having suffered from the 
2008–2009  crisis,  and  display  continued  refinancing  and  liquidity  problems  together  with 
worrying asset quality, which constrain their ability to serve the growing demand for MSME 
lending. Improving access to finance for entrepreneurs along with healthy competition among 
banks and MFIs is essential to improve access and financing conditions for clients, whose 
investments will support job creation and retention and offer alternatives to migration to cities 
and internationally, while reducing poverty in the regions.  
 
9.  Of the existing financial institutions, only a few banks and MFIs will achieve the financial 
strength to become commercially oriented and lasting service providers for local communities. 
Unfavorable ownership and governance in a business environment characterized by integrity 
issues further reduce the number of suitable financial institutions to provide services that are fair 
and responsible to their customers, and the necessary assurance to depositors. The greenfield 
banking approach is an option for providing lasting financial services to low-income customers; 
it  has  been  successfully  tested  in  several  post-conflict  economies.  This  approach  entails 
creating a financial institution, in most cases a bank owned by a technology and knowledge 
provider, in association with strong investors, in most cases international financial institutions 
(IFIs). The investors share a long-term vision of building a strong, profitable financial institution, 
and  exercise  influence  to  promote  internal  and  external  governance  best  practices  and 
adherence to international industry standards, such as customer protection and social and 
environmental  responsibility.  High-quality  selection  and  training  of  staff  and  management; 
strong  internal  rules  for  integrity  and  responsibility  toward  customers,  associated  with  no 
tolerance for corruption; and resources to weather crises that may adversely affect a greenfield 
financial institution during its buildup period, are essential components of the approach. 
 
10.  The TA is an integral part of an anticipated ADB investment that includes an equity 
investment and a loan to ABTJ. ABTJ was established as a greenfield bank in April 2010 and 
currently services over 7,000 customers in six branches with an average loan size of about 
$4,500. Since the receipt of a deposit license in late 2012, the bank is focusing on deposit

3 
 
mobilization from small savers and the lower-income population. Access Microfinance Holding 
Aktiengesellschaft, Berlin (AMH) owns 63.4% of the shares of ABTJ; the International Finance 
Corporation and the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development each own 13.7%; and 
KfW owns 9.1%. AMH is owned by its strategic investor and knowledge provider Luso Financial 
Systems GmbH (LFS) with 14.2%; and LFS staff through Micro Assets (Berlin) with 4.5% of 
shares;  CDC  Group  (United  Kingdom),  European  Investment  Bank,  International  Finance 
Corporation,  KfW  (Germany),  and  Omidyar  Tufts,  each  with  14.2%;  and  Financierings-
Maatschappij voor Ontwikkelingslanden N.V. (Netherlands) with 10% of the shares.3 ABTJ’s 
highly reputable owners make the bank an excellent target for investment to improve access to 
finance for low-income households and small and micro businesses. 
 
11.  The TA is needed to test and train employees in a rigorous manner to build capacity 
within service teams in branches. This may take up to 2 years per branch. ABTJ shareholders 
have so far provided critical TA grant funding to support the bank’s build-up phase. Further TA 
needs are substantial, especially for managing expansion, supporting product development, and 
building branch capacity in lending and deposit taking to transform ABTJ into a leading bank in 
a challenging business environment. As the history of the Access Microfinance bank network, in 
general,  and  of  ABTJ,  in  particular,  concretely  shows,  training  efforts  directly  translate  to 
improved staff productivity, thus leading to more clients accessed and serviced, which has a 
direct development and income impact In Tajikistan and a demonstration effect to the sector. 
 
12.  ABTJ now plans to expand its client outreach to borrowers and depositors in rural areas 
through additional branches, providing new agricultural financing products to farmers, as well as 
lending to MSMEs. ABTJ development plans for 2014–2018 include (i) developing an additional 
17 branches and outlets (of which 14 will be in regions outside the capital); (ii) employing  
300 additional staff (of which 260 will be in the regions); (iii) introducing several products in 
credit and banking services departments; and (iv) increasing the outstanding loan portfolio from 
the current $32 million to $135 million (of which up to $11 million will be agricultural loans), to 
grow total deposits from $1 million currently to $28 million, and to maintain profitability and earn  
$3.5 million by the end of 2017. Along with this business growth, ABTJ would provide access to 
finance to 20,000 additional borrowers, most of whom are in the regions.  
 
13.  ABTJ has been selected as a partner because of its high potential for quality growth and 
outreach  to  low-income,  and  micro  and  small  business  customers  in  rural  areas;  its  solid 
governance  structure  and  internal  controls  supported  by  its  IFI  and  strategic  investor 
shareholders;  and  its  active  pursuit  of  responsible  finance  principles  aligned  with  modern 
consumer rights. ABTJ actively pursues equal opportunity employment and access to financial 
services. Currently, more than 2,300 clients and 36% of its employees, including its chief 
executive officer, are female. AMH´s experience in building sustainable greenfield banks in 
fragile economic environments provides important confidence in the selection of ABTJ. The TA 
will have a demonstration effect in strengthening banking institutions in the nascent finance 
sector. 
 
14.  Consistent with the Tajikistan country partnership strategy and Tajikistan’s long-term 
national  development  strategy,  2006–2015,  the  TA,  as  part  of  an  overall  ADB  investment 
package, aims to provide a model for sustainable financial inclusion of Tajikistan’s farmers and 
private enterprises with a special focus on rural areas. This access to financial services in 
                                                 
3  AMH, a holding company, currently owns seven greenfield banks in five African countries (Liberia, Madagascar, 
Nigeria, Tanzania, and Zambia) as well as in two Central Asian countries (Azerbaijan and Tajikistan). LFS provides 
advisory services to those entities through management contracts.

4 
underserved regions and economic sectors will provide support for inclusive growth through 
employment  and  income  generation  in  underdeveloped  local  communities.  The  TA  and 
proposed investment will be closely coordinated with ADB’s ongoing sovereign activities in 
support of microfinance and financial inclusion.  
 
15.  While the TA will directly benefit ABTJ sustainability, the massive training effort will 
benefit many individuals who are likely to be absorbed by other financial institutions after 
completion of the training. Therefore, the TA will have substantial positive spillover effects to 
other Tajik banks, and demonstrate the potential of lending to small businesses, thus reducing 
income poverty in a fragile economic environment. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
16.  The TA impact will be to help ABTJ become a sustainable greenfield bank serving as a 
model for nascent economies. The outcome will be an improved rural ABTJ branch network. 
The impact will be measured by the frequency of other financial institutions adopting responsible 
finance  policies  and  ABTJ-specific  performance  metrics  of  profitability,  asset  quality,  and 
national and rural client outreach by 2018 (Appendix 1). 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
17.  The TA has four outputs: rural branches established and profitable, adequate portfolio 
quality, loan officers trained, and financial literacy training provided to customers.  
 
18.  The TA will build ABTJ capacity by providing classroom and on-the-job training in credit 
analysis, risk management, and staff integrity. Financial literacy training of customers will be 
provided  in  line  with  Consultative  Group  to  Assist  the  Poor  (CGAP)  responsible  finance 
principles.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
19.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,026,000, of which (i) $200,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund4 and administered by ADB; and 
(ii) $300,000 will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund 
(TASF-V). The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. The remaining cost of the 
TA is to be funded by ABTJ in the context of its ongoing management service contract with LFS, 
which includes external expert support, seminars, and training.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
20.  ABTJ is the beneficiary of the TA. Administration of the TA will be delegated to LFS, 
which holds 14.2% of AMH’s shares. LFS executes a management contract for ABTJ as it does 
for other banks of the Access Microfinance bank network. LFS is intimately familiar with the 
requirements of ABTJ and is most capable of developing the terms of reference, and managing 
the consulting services. Individual consulting assignments are most appropriate as these allow 
LFS to identify experienced experts and are more cost-effective than contracting a firm. The TA 
will  require  63  person-months  of  inputs  from  long-term  experts  in  charge  of  (i)  regional 
                                                 
4  Contributor: the Government of Luxembourg.

5 
 
operations (outside the capital city); (ii) branch expansion, supervision, and training; and (iii) 
branch  management  as  further  described  in  detail  in  the  Outline  terms  of  reference  for 
consultants in Appendix 3.  
 
21.  AMH and LFS, its strategic investor, have successfully established and operate six 
MSME finance banks in challenging African and Central Asian markets and in this context have 
adopted adequate processes for procurement and management of consulting services, as well 
as internal and external audits in line with IFI policies and requirements and with their IFI 
shareholders. The competitive selection and management of individual experts will be delegated 
to LFS in line with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013) and Technical Assistance 
Disbursement Handbook (2010), each as amended from time to time, and as supervised by the 
Private Sector Operations Department in accordance with a TA agreement. The TA is to be 
implemented from March 2014 to June 2016. The TA closing date will be 31 December 2016. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) ADB 
administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $200,000 to be 
financed on a grant basis by the Financial Sector Development Partnership Fund, and (ii) ADB 
providing  the  balance  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $300,000  on  a  grant  basis,  to 
AccessBank Tajikistan Joint Stock Company, for Capacity Building for Rural Financial Inclusion 
in Tajikistan and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  Access Microfinance Holding, along with a group of international investors, established 
AccessBank Tajikistan (ABTJ) in April 2010. ABTJ’s mission is to provide commercially viable 
sustainable financial services, especially credit, targeted to private micro and small businesses 
and to farmers in Tajikistan. ABTJ has its head office and four branches in Dushanbe and two 
rural branches in Khojand and Tursunzoda in the northern and western part of Tajikistan. ABTJ 
is planning to expand its rural branch network by at least two branches per year during 2014–
2017, and aims to serve its target customers in selected urban and rural markets throughout the 
country. In March 2013, ABTJ realized its first monthly profit and expects a positive net income 
for fiscal year 2013. ABTJ shareholders support the investment to have a demonstration effect 
on banking, and the commercial viability of micro and small business and rural finance, while 
respecting responsible finance principles.  
 
2.  ABTJ offers the following loan products (current average loan size of $4,700):  
(i)  Micro loans in all sectors and agriculture loans for individual businesses, firms, or 
farmers requiring financing up to $20,000. Adequate cash-flow analysis and, to a 
limited extent, collateral requirements, simplified analysis, and local approval 
procedures characterize the product. Loans are extended in Tajik somoni (TJS) 
or dollars ($) and do not exceed 36-month tenors. 
(ii)  Small loans (TJS or $) for individual businesses or firms in all sectors requiring 
financing up to $500,000.  
 
3.  ABTJ also offers banking products for its customers and employees, such as current 
accounts and deposit accounts, in both TJS and $ money transfer and international payment 
services. ABTJ is building up its retail deposit base as the ultimate source of funding for its 
lending operations, and aims to become gradually independent from funding provided by its 
shareholders and lenders. LFS Financial Systems (LFS) will contract and manage consulting 
services based on a technical assistance (TA) agreement to be signed with ABTJ, LFS, and 
Access Microfinance Holding Aktiengesellschaft, Berlin (AMH).  
 
4.  The TA will be implemented over 33 months. ABTJ is expected to reach profitability and 
a  business  size  and  quality  within  this  period,  limiting  future  TA  requirements  to  regional 
expansion, development of new products, and financial literacy training. ABTJ is expected to 
develop a branch presence in at least four regions of Tajikistan by the end of 2017. The TA will 
support ABTJ in establishing branches and building up lending capacity. 
 
5.  Reporting to the general manager of ABTJ and LFS, and supervised by staff of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) Private Sector Operations Department with Access Holding, the 
experts will carry out the following tasks: 
(i)  Conduct  market  research,  and  establish  and  develop  at  least  three  rural 
branches to expand ABTJ’s lending and other activities to Tajikistan’s regions. 
(ii)  Develop appropriate management and controls in the rural branches. 
(iii)  Review and recommend improvements for ABTJ’s risk management and asset 
liability management structures and capabilities. 
(iv)  Screen,  select,  and  train  at  least  120  trainee  loan  officers  in  appropriate 
techniques of analysis, monitoring, and recovery or workout of loans through a 
combination of theoretical seminars and intensive on-the-job training. 
(v)  Train other personnel for operations at headquarters and branches. 
(vi)  Provide regular and detailed reporting to ADB and ABTJ shareholders on ABTJ, 
its rural branch outreach program, and its lending to target customers.

6.  The  expert  inputs  will  include  the  review  of  lending  and  risk  management  and 
responsible finance policies and procedures, and the selection of suitable trainees to grow into 
qualified lending staff. The TA will require 63 person-months of inputs from long-term experts in 
charge of (i) regional operations (outside the capital city); (ii) branch expansion, supervision, 
and training; and (iii) branch management. A total of 18.5 person-months of inputs will be 
required from short-term experts on risk management, governance, responsible finance, and 
training.  The  expert  candidates  will  have  professional  experience  in  the  region  covering 
commercial micro and small business lending, loans to farmers, training local credit staff in 
lending techniques, implementing organizational structures and procedures to support lending 
activities, and overseeing day-to-day operations. Hands-on experience with setting up and 
managing branches as profit centers is also a requirement. Fluency in the Russian language is 
required. LFS will prepare detailed Terms of Reference for the individual expert positions to be 
funded by ADB, and subsequently advertise and select the individual consultants in line with the 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013), as amended from time to time, and in close 
consultation with ADB.     
 
7.  Credit advisers and/or branch managers will support ABTJ expansion to regions outside 
Dushanbe. The experts will strengthen the ABTJ management team in training a large number 
of local credit officers and other staff to work for ABTJ mainly in the rural branches. Support to 
head office staff will be related to risk management and responsible finance training efforts. The 
regions will be jointly selected by ABTJ in consultation with its shareholders and ADB based on 
the level of farming, micro and small business activity, and demand for finance. The branch 
managers will be responsible for (i) selecting and training branch staff; (ii) intensive on-the-job 
training  of  branch  management  and  loan  officers  in  all  lending  products;  
(iii) cooperating with ABTJ headquarters (especially the general manager and members of the 
senior management team) on business aspects regarding branch development and expansion; 
(iv) coaching and training key staff; (v) establishing a profitable retail lending business; and  
(vi) establishing training and controls for sound staff integrity and financial literacy of its target 
customers. Local staff is expected to gradually assume greater management responsibility. 
 
8.  A training specialist will coordinate the training of at least 120 loan officers. The selection 
and training of appropriate loan officers plays a key role to ensure sound business, strong 
growth, and profitability, while exercising respect of consumer rights. All potential loan officers 
will start as trainees and must undergo a 3-month training course, followed by a 9-month 
probation program, comprising two phases. Only those trainees who successfully complete the 
initial phase will be allowed to enter the final stage of training. After initial training, the loan 
officers  should  be  able  to  identify  suitable  customers,  analyze  their  credit  strength,  and 
supervise the disbursement and repayment of loans. The loan officer training will cover the 
following broad topics: (i) analysis of micro and small enterprises and farm operations; (ii) 
monitoring of loans; (iii) generation of profitable lending volumes, while respecting responsible 
finance principles; and (iv) management of loan portfolio growth. 
 
9.  ABTJ will provide the trainees with a stipend during the training program and sign 
apprenticeship contracts with ABTJ. Qualified trainees will be offered formal employment with 
ABTJ at the latest by the end of the apprenticeship.  
 
10.  By December 2017, ABTJ should have achieved the following results. 
 
(i)  ABTJ is a commercially sustainable bank providing financial services to its target 
customers (micro and small businesses and farmers).

Appendix 3          11 
(ii)  At least three additional branches are established in the regions covered under 
the TA. 
(iii)  For  ongoing  branch  lending  under  the  TA,  monthly  loan  disbursements  will 
exceed 100 loans for all new regional branches. 
(iv)  The share of ABTJ’s portfolio at risk (loans in arrears >30 days) does not exceed 
5%. 
(v)  At least 120 trainees will have been trained in credit analysis, and current loan 
applications in branch credit committees will no longer require further external 
assistance. 
(vi)  Branch credit committees are able to make independent lending decisions. 
(vii)  Branches funded by this TA will have graduated from TA support within 18 
months. 
 
11.  ADB will monitor the TA through regular field visits to Tajikistan, board meetings, and 
telephone contact. Periodic reporting to ADB and all shareholders will include the following 
mechanisms: 
(i)  Quarterly  lending  statistics  of  lending  in  the  prior  period. This includes 
branch-by-branch information of the amount and number of loans disbursed; 
amount and number of loans outstanding; maturity structure, sector, number of 
employees,  currency,  borrower,  and  average  loan  size;  and  a  review  of  all 
problem loans, with arrears to be broken down into 1–15, 16–30, 31–60, 60–90, 
and more than 90 days. Reports will be submitted within 15 days of the end of 
each quarter. 
(ii)  Quarterly management reports on ABTJ progress for all banking activities, 
training,  and  branch  expansion. This includes a description of issues that 
require resolution by ADB and the ABTJ’s shareholders, as well as points the 
experts would like to bring to the attention of ADB and the shareholders. Planned 
initiatives in the forthcoming quarter will be included. The report will cover all TA 
tasks and measure progress of ABTJ in becoming a sustainable institution and 
reaching its rural footprint. Reports will be submitted within 30 days of the end of 
each quarter. 
(iii)  Ad hoc topic communication as required. This will describe particular issues 
that warrant examination and immediate feedback, including legal and regulatory 
issues. 
(iv)  A final report. This will include the status of the project, lessons, a description of 
tasks undertaken, and measurement of the TA impact and outputs; as well as 
provide an outlook on future ABTJ prospects. The report will be delivered to 
ABTJ (copy to ADB) within 30 days after the contract completion date.
